Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: A binding client contract cannot be finalized until they provide precise effort estimates
Story: I sat at my desk, laptop open, spreadsheets and timelines blurring together. My phone buzzed with a message from Mom: “Can you call tonight? Dad’s been quiet lately.” I knew what she wanted—just to talk, to check in, to feel like I was there for them. I glanced at the clock. The project planning meeting was in twenty minutes, and my manager had already reminded me twice that the client was waiting on my effort estimates. Without them, the contract couldn’t move forward, and the whole team was depending on me. My mind raced, torn between dialing home and running through the numbers one more time. I could hear Mom’s voice in my head, gentle but worried, and at the same time, I felt the weight of my team’s expectations pressing down. I wanted to be the daughter who noticed when something was off at home, but I was also the engineer who couldn’t let everyone down. My heart pounded as I stared at my phone, caught between two worlds, unsure which one needed me more right now.
